bestBHT.bht: As Christians, we are called to pray for the government and its leaders, seeking peace and order in our state. Our prayers have the power to bring down peace from heaven and influence the welfare of thousands. We ask for tranquil and quiet lives where we can behave with propriety among others. We should pray for the conversion of rulers and their inclination to do what is right. Through our prayers, we seek a peaceful life and the preservation of godliness promoted by our rulers.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The prayers of Christians for the government bring down from heaven peace and order in a state.
He is peaceable (Greek) who makes no disturbance; he is quiet (Greek) who is himself free from disturbance.
As 'piety' is in relation to God, 'gravity' is propriety of behavior among men.
Albert Barnes: The salvation of a king is of itself of no more importance than that of a peasant or a slave; but the welfare of thousands may depend on him, and hence he should be made the special subject of prayer.
The happiness of all who are under their control depends greatly on them, and hence we should pray for them that they may be converted people, and inclined to do that which is right.
Christians are disposed of themselves to be peaceful and orderly; they ask of their rulers only that they may not be harassed in the enjoyment of their rights.
Marvin Vincent: This very phrase is found in an inscription of the early Roman period, after 133 B. 100, at Pergamum.
Hremov denotes quiet arising from the absence of outward disturbance; hJouciov tranquillity arising from within.
Honesty, according to the modern acceptation, is an unfortunate rendering. In earlier English, it signified becoming department, decency, decorum.
John Calvin: The apostle meets this difficulty, and expressly enjoins Christians to pray for them also.
The first is a peaceful life; for magistrates are armed with the sword, in order to keep us in peace.

The second fruit is the preservation of godliness, that is, when magistrates give themselves to promote religion, to maintain the worship of God, and to take care that sacred ordinances be observed with due reverence.
Philip Schaff: Prayers of the kind spoken of are found (as now in the Prayer of the Church Militant in the English Communion Office) in all ancient liturgies.
To pray for the Emperor was the way to quiet and safety.
'Godliness' and 'piety' are both fair representatives of its meaning, the former being that uniformly adopted by the Authorised Version.
Archibald T. Robertson: For kings... and all them that are in high place... that we may lead tranquil and quiet lives.
Gravity... in N.T. only here, 1 Timothy 3:4; Titus 2:7.
John Gill: For supreme governors, as the emperor of Rome, and kings of particular nations; and for all sub-governors, or inferior magistrates, as procurators or governors of provinces...
which does not merely design the end of civil government by kings and magistrates, which is to preserve the peace and quiet of the commonwealth...

Prayer should be made...that he would either convert them, and bring them to the knowledge of the truth, they now persecuted; or at least so dispose their hearts and minds, that they might stop the persecution...
John Wesley: God supports the power of magistracy for the sake of his own people, when, in the present state of men, it could not otherwise be kept up in any nation whatever.
Godliness — Inward religion; the true worship of God.
Honesty — A comprehensive word taking in the whole duty we owe to our neighbour.

bhtAttempts.bht: As Christians, we are called to pray for our government and its leaders, seeking peace and order for our state. This involves praying for their conversion and that they may be inclined to do what is right. We ask for tranquil and quiet lives, where we can live with propriety in our behavior among others. Our prayers have the power to bring down peace from heaven and influence the welfare of thousands. Ultimately, we seek a peaceful life and the preservation of godliness, where our rulers promote religion and maintain the worship of God.

Christians are called to pray for the government, as their prayers bring peace and order to the state. We are to seek a peaceful and quiet life, where our behavior displays decency and decorum. Our prayers for those in high positions can have a significant impact on the welfare of many. It is important to pray for the conversion of rulers and for them to promote and maintain godliness. Through our prayers, we can influence the preservation of inward religion and the proper treatment of our neighbors.

As Christians, we are called to pray for the government and its leaders, seeking peace and order in our state. Our prayers have the power to bring down peace from heaven and influence the welfare of thousands. We ask for tranquil and quiet lives where we can behave with propriety among others. We should pray for the conversion of rulers and their inclination to do what is right. Through our prayers, we seek a peaceful life and the preservation of godliness promoted by our rulers.

Christians are called to pray for the government, bringing down peace and order in the state. We are to seek tranquil and quiet lives, behaving with propriety among others. Through our prayers, we can influence the welfare of thousands and the preservation of godliness. Praying for the conversion of rulers and their inclination to do what is right is crucial. Our prayers have the power to promote religion and maintain the worship of God, ensuring a peaceful and orderly society.

As believers, it is our duty to pray for our government and its leaders, for our prayers have the power to bring peace and order to our state. We should seek to lead tranquil and quiet lives, displaying decency and decorum in our behavior. Through our prayers, we can have an impact on the welfare of thousands and promote godliness. It is important to pray for the conversion of rulers and for them to uphold the worship of God, ensuring a peaceful and orderly society.
